data.title: Windows 8.1 Universal on Phone - Graphics Glitch on Startup
data.body:
This bug occurs with Windows 8.1 Universal projects and the default Monogame templates running the latest nightly build (6/18/15, as well as 3.4 release builds).

We notice that very often on app startup, there is perhaps half a second where the graphics do not take up the full screen. This happens both on the Windows Phone Emulator and on a Lumia 920 test device. We do not see it when creating Windows Phone 8.0 projects, or when running on the desktop.

You can see it very clearly in this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAWHxEiTdnw

As the app starts up, it first renders to the top half of the screen. After half a second, rendering starts happening like normal.

Please let me know if any other information is needed to get a repro of this issue.

data.title: AlphaTestEffect using GraphicsDevice.DrawUserIndexedPrimitives not working on iOS nor Mac
data.body:
Hey guys.

I have been testing every platform out there and iOS and Mac are the only platforms that presents a problem with this.

I have attached an example, StencilsCratersTutorial3, which contains two platforms, Android and iOS, linked against the most recent MonoGame NuGet packages.  This is basically the same tutorial from XNA's StencilsCratersTutorial.

There are two Game implementations included.  
- GameSpriteBatch - using a sprite batch.  Works on all platforms
- GameDrawPrimitives - using DrawUserIndexPrimitives to implement the same functionality as the first but does not work on iOS and Mac.  Also, does not use RenderTargets but that should not matter.

To see the differences just change:

```
        var game = new GameDrawPrimitives();
```

to 
            var game = new GameSpriteBatch();

When the planet comes up just touch around on the planet and there should be holes cut into the planet.  On iOS using SpriteBatch it works fine but doing the same with DrawUserIndexedPrimitives it is not working.  Have tested on all windows platforms and they seem fine as well.

You can find a link to the project file here: [StencilCratersTutorial3](https://www.dropbox.com/s/tjys5njhslczwvh/StencilsCratersTutorial3.zip?dl=0)

Any help in getting this working would be greatly appreciated.

Also, let me know if another platform implementation would be necessary and I will provide it.

You can find a link to the project file here: [StencilCratersTutorial3](https://www.dropbox.com/s/tjys5njhslczwvh/StencilsCratersTutorial3.zip?dl=0)

data.title: graphics change
ReadRawAsset for SpriteFont needs to be implemented
data.body:
I hope my conclusion of what the issue should be is correct, but to be sure I will elaborate more.
As I was searching how to draw strings I found a lot of old methods that have been replaced by the new MonoGame Content Pipeline now. To create a .spritefont file with the Pipeline is pretty straightforward and gives no problems, but then it needs to be loaded.
Using content.Load<SpriteFont> throws a NotImplementedException because this leads to a call to ReadRasAsset, which throws that exception when the Type is SpriteFont (with a contruction of a SpriteFont in comment).
If I am correct this means that there is no way to load SpriteFonts at the moment and as you need a SpriteFont to draw a string it is also impossible to draw text at the moment. Thus it is important that this is implemented soon.

Looking at the created .spritefont file however I wonder if the SpriteFont class is meant to be abolished.  I thought this because it states <Asset Type="Graphics:FontDescription">, leading me to think that the type is to be changed to FontDescription. This type does not exist yet however. I was not able to find anything about this possible change however.

Finally I'm sorry if I just misunderstood the way drawing strings must be done now and I simply addressed problems that are not there. I would like to hear so if this is the case however.

data.title: Isue with Song.FromURI Android
data.body:
The way Song.FromUri works on andoird is wrong. 

For example
Song.FromUri("Menu Track 1", new Uri("Content/Audio/Music/MENU.mp3", UriKind.Relative)

The above code is how it should work but the name is been used to locate the file and not the uri so this is the workaround

Song.FromUri("Content/Audio/Music/MENU.mp3", new Uri("Content/Audio/Music/MENU.mp3", UriKind.Relative)

data.title: Interpolate curved animation
data.body:
`AnimationContent` behavior closer to XNA. This makes possible to work with custom importers ported from/to XNA without changing the importer or exporting again the FBX/animation.

XNA generates 60 keyframes per frame for every bone for the full duration of the animation.
For those keyframes it seems that it samples/lerp the animation. Keyframes in the FBX that don't fall on the right intervals are dropped.

data.title: [pipeline] Added support for attaching the mono debugger to MGCB via the pipeline tool
data.body:
One feature that was missing in the pipeline tool was the ability to
debug your extensions via the UI. This commit adds that support
by providing the appropriate command line arguments to mono
which will cause the app to pause and wait for the debugger to
attach. A suitable warning message is included to make sure
the developer knows they are in debug mode.

If you want to specify your won debugger port this can be done
by exporting the MONO_DEBUGGER_PORT environment variable 
BEFORE running the pipeline tool. e.g.

export MONO_DEBUGGER_PORT=1235

Curve.Evaluate ArgumentOutOfRangeException when no keys added
Xml compile and load fails: Empty list of custom type containing an enum
[SkinnedModelProcessor] struct Keyframe
data.body:
Convert Keyframe to struct.
Instead of allocating a large number of Keyframes and add each one on a
List<Keyframe> we now allocate a single array of structs.
The idea is to keep a low heap complexity (number of live objects &
number of object references) for the GC.

Also this will improve loading times and required memory by a small
factor.
